An `NSString` object that is used for editing the textual representation of `anObject`.

## Discussion

When implementing a subclass, override this method only when the string that users see and the string that they edit are different. In your implementation, return an `NSString` object that is used for editing, following the logic recommended for implementing [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/Formatter/string(for:)]. As an example, you would implement this method if you want the dollar signs in displayed strings removed for editing.

# editingString(for:)

**Instance Method**

The default implementation of this method invokes [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/Formatter/string(for:)].

## Declaration

```swift
func editingString(for obj: Any) -> String?
```

## Parameters

- **obj**: The object for which to return an editing string.

## Return Value

An `NSString` object that is used for editing the textual representation of `anObject`.

## Discussion

When implementing a subclass, override this method only when the string that users see and the string that they edit are different. In your implementation, return an `NSString` object that is used for editing, following the logic recommended for implementing [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/Formatter/string(for:)]. As an example, you would implement this method if you want the dollar signs in displayed strings removed for editing.

## Getting Textual Representations of Object Values

- **string(for:)**: The default implementation of this method raises an exception.
- **attributedString(for:withDefaultAttributes:)**: The default implementation returns `nil` to indicate that the formatter object does not provide an attributed string.
